titleStmt.title: Anti-EGFR antibody conjugated thiol chitosan-layered gold nanoshells for dual-modal imaging-guided cancer combination therapy

funder.orgName: Ministry of Science and ICT, Republic of Korea
Ministry of Oceans and Fisheries, Republic of Korea

analytic.title: Anti-EGFR antibody conjugated thiol chitosan-layered gold nanoshells for dual-modal imaging-guided cancer combination therapy

biblStruct.note: Received 11 April 2019; Received in revised form 6 August 2019; Accepted 7 August 2019

textClass.keywords: Gold nanoshells Chitosan Paclitaxel Photothermal therapy Photoacoustic imaging

div.p: Developing a novel multifunctional theranostic agent for cancer combination therapy has attracted tremendous attention in recent years. In this report, we designed and developed a new multifunctional nanocarrier based on anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody-conjugated and paclitaxel loaded-thiol chitosan-layered gold nanoshells (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) as a theranostic agent for the first time used for fluorescence/photoacoustic dual-modal imaging-guided chemophotothermal synergistic therapy. The resulting anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs showed excellent biosafety, biocompatibility, broad near-infrared (NIR) absorbance, photostability, fast and laser irradiation-controllable drug release, and higher targeting efficiency for efficient chemophotothermal combination therapy of cancer under the guidance of photoacoustic imaging (PAI). The combination therapy was investigated in vitro and in vivo, displaying a powerful anticancer efficiency. More importantly, an in vivo experiment of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs with laser irradiation showed heavy damage to the tumor tissue, killing the tumor cells almost completely. Anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs also showed a powerful capacity to visualize tumors, and therefore it is considered a new PAI contrast agent for subsequent therapy. Histological analysis and TUNEL assay further showed much more apoptotic cells, confirming the value of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs. Our results provide a new concept and a promising strategy to develop a novel multifunctional nanotheranostic agent for future clinical applications in diagnosis and therapy.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Applications of biocompatible nanomaterials as multifunctional theranostic agents that combine diagnosis and therapy have recently been developed for use in disease treatment because of the various advantages of the reduced rate of recurrent tumors and minimized side effects [1][2][3]. In particular, combination therapies such as photoacoustic imaging (PAI), chemotherapy, and photothermal therapy (PTT) have recently attracted a great deal of attention because of their good biosafety, deep penetration, highly targeted nature, and noninvasiveness, which can significantly enhance the therapeutic efficacy [4][5][6]. PAI is considered to be an emerging method and has deeper tissue penetration and higher spatial resolution, which can be used for precise anatomical localization of a tumor [7][8][9]. Chemotherapy is still the best choice in cancer treatment because of its high efficiency [10]. PTT has recently drawn considerable attention as a minimally invasive therapeutic technique to ablate cancer cells, which uses nanoparticles that absorb near-infrared (NIR) light to convert laser light energy into cytotoxic heat to ablate the cancer cells [11][12][13]. This technique has several advantages such as high selectivity, harmlessness, and minimal damage to surrounding normal cells [14].

In recent years, NIR-light-absorbing nanoparticles have been proposed for photothermal ablation cancer therapy [15,16]. Gold-based nanomaterials have also attracted extensive attention as excellent candidates for PTT because of their good biocompatibility and low toxicity [17]. In particular, gold nanoshells (GNSs) commonly contain a silica core and a thin layer of gold. GNSs are considered a promising material for significantly enhancing the photothermal efficiency because of their high photothermal conductivity and strong absorption in the NIR region [18][19][20]. For further enhancement of polymer coating and anticancer drug loading, higher targeting, and a better therapeutic efficiency, a variety of thiol chitosan (TCS), paclitaxel (PTX), and antiepidermal growth factor receptor (anti-EGFR) antibodies have been conjugated to the GNS surface [21].

Chitosan (CS) is a positively charged biopolymer that has attracted much attention in the biomedical field as a biomaterial because of its biocompatibility, biodegradability, and nontoxicity [22]. However, the only drawback of CS is mainly its poor solubility at normal pH [23]. In order to solve this problem of CS, various derivatives of CS (e.g., TCS) have been recently used for biomedical applications. TCS is highly water-soluble, has a low molecular weight, and biocompatible [24]. Dithiol ligands, including lipoic acid (LA) has a disulfide-containing lipoic ring that is commonly used to bind to the surface of GNSs; this dithiol-gold linkage is very strong, offering long-term stability [25,26]. PTX is an anticancer drug that is commonly used for the treatment of breast and ovarian cancer [27,28]. However, the main drawback of PTX is its poor solubility in its natural form [29]. In order to overcome these limitations of PTX, various drug delivery vehicles (e.g., polymer) have been recently developed to increase the solubility of PTX and to reduce its side effects. Among these investigations, novel multifunctional polymeric nanoparticles as a drug delivery system have received much attention in the recent years [30].

EGFR is a cell-surface receptor that is overexpressed in various cancer cells, including the breast, ovaries, bladder, lungs, prostate, and kidneys making it an attractive target for theranostic applications [31]. This receptor has emerged as an attractive therapeutic target for targeted drug delivery and PTT [32]. Meanwhile, owing to their specificity for EGFR overexpressing tumor cells, monoclonal antibodies (anti-EGFR) have been developed as a specific ligand to guide nanocarriers to specifically kill cancer cells [33]. The use of anti-epidermal growth factor receptor antibody-conjugated and paclitaxel loaded-thiol chitosan-layered gold nanoshells (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) as a multifunctional theranostic agent has attracted increasing attention for the first time, used for NIR laser-triggered drug release in combined chemophotothermal therapy under the guidance of PAI, because of their excellent biosafety, biocompatibility, stability, broad NIR absorbance, photothermal stability, high drug loading capabilities, fast and laser irradiation-controllable drug release, and high targeting efficiency. In this work, we report the use of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs as a theranostic agent for fluorescence (FL)/photoacoustic (PA) dual-modal imaging-guided chemophotothermal synergistic therapy.

div.head: Materials
div.p: Most of the reagents and materials were obtained from Sigma-Aldrich and were used as received.

div.head: Preparation of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs
div.p: GNSs containing silica cores with thin GNS layer formation were synthesized using the modified Oldenburg method [34]. Silica cores (120 nm) were synthesized using the Stöber method [35]. For GNS layer formation, the silica cores were coated with gold colloids (~9 nm) synthesized by following an earlier reported method [36]. For the depolymerization of CS, 1 g of CS (MW: 50-190 kDa, 85% deacetylation degree) fully dissolved in 2% acetic acid solution (100 mL), and CS were prepared according to the literature [37,38]. CS was freeze-dried and stored for further use.

For the surface coating of GNSs, 1.0 g of CS was fully dissolved in 25 mL of deionized water (DW), and the free amino groups of CS were reacted with the carboxyl groups of dithiol ligands such as lipoic acid (LA; 0.247 g, 2.4 mM) through a coupling reaction in the presence of 1-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)-3-ethylcarbodiimide hydrochloride (EDC•HCl; 0.288 g, 3 mM) and N-hydroxysulfosuccinimide sodium (sulfo-NHS; 0.651 g, 6 mM) for 24 h at room temperature and CS-LA (TCS) was then freeze-dried [25,39,40]. Thiol chitosan (TCS; 1 mg/mL) was added to 20 mL of GNSs through gold-thiol interaction for 24 h at room temperature. The TCS-layered GNSs (TCS-GNSs) were purified by certification, washed three times in DW to remove unreacted TCS, and then freeze-dried.

PTX loaded onto TCS-GNSs was synthesized according to earlier reports [41][42][43]. 1.155 g of TCS-GNSs and 0.79 g of 3,3′-dithiodipropionic acid (DTPA; 15.6 mM) were completely dissolved in 10 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), followed by adding trimethylamine (0.79 g, 15.6 mM) in the mixture solution and then stirring at ambient temperature overnight. DTPA-TCS-GNSs were prepared via a condensation reaction between PTX and DTPA-TCS-GNSs using dimethylaminopyridine (DMAP) as a catalytic agent and diisopropylcarbodiimide (DIC) as a condensing agent. Briefly, 0.44 g of DTPA-TCS-GNSs, 0.128 g of PTX (0.3 mM), and 18 mg of DMAP were dissolved in 5 mL of DMF for 12 h and then 0.075 g of DIC was added to the reaction solution. The reaction solution was then stirred at ambient temperature overnight, and the solution was dialyzed against DMF to remove unbound molecules. PTX-TCS-GNSs were then freeze-dried and stored for further use.

For the conjugation of anti-EGFR antibodies on the surface of PTX-TCS-GNSs, 5 μL of anti-EGFR monoclonal antibody solution was dissolved in 1 mL of phosphate-buffered saline (PBS) and treated with EDC/NHS (1 mg, 0.005 mM) for 30 min at ambient temperature. Free amino groups of PTX-TCS-GNSs (0.5 mg) were added to the reaction solution and stirred at ambient temperature for 16 h. The anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNS solutions were centrifuged, washed with PBS, redispersed in PBS, and then freeze-dried. The antibody conjugation efficiency was determined by bicinchoninic acid (BCA) protein assay kit (Pierce) [44]. The degree of amino acid substitution was measured using the 2,4,6-trinitrobenzenesulfonic acid (TNBS) method [45].

div.head: Characterization
div.p: The structural and chemical composition and the size of the nanomaterials were characterized using field emission transmission electron microscopy (FETEM, Model JEM-2100F; JEOL, Tokyo, Japan) and energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) attached to the FETEM. Imaging of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was performed in the highangle annular dark-field (HAADF)-scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM) mode and EDX mappings were obtained in STEM mode (Model TEM 2010F, JEOL, Tokyo, Japan). The absorbance spectra were determined using an ultraviolet-visible (UV-vis) spectrophotometer (Genesys 30S; Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). Dynamic light scattering (DLS) measurements and surface zeta potential (ZP) of the nanomaterials were measured using an electrophoretic light scattering spectrophotometer (ELS-8000; Otsuka Electronics Co. Ltd., Osaka, Japan). Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were characterized with a PerkinElmer Spectrum 100 spectrometer (PerkinElmer, Waltham, MA, USA). The chemical structures of CS, LA, and TCS were characterized by nuclear magnetic resonance spectra ( 1 H NMR), and the 1 H NMR spectra were recorded in D 2 O on a JNM ECP-400 spectrometer (400 MHz; JEOL, Japan). Thermogravimetric analysis curves were investigated using a Perkin-Elmer Pyris Diamond TG/DTA thermogravimetric/differential thermal analyzer (USA). The gold (Au) ion concentration of the nanomaterials was quantified by an inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometer (ICP-MS; PerkinElmer-NexION 300D, PerkinElmer Corporation, USA). An NIR laser at 808 nm (Changchun New Industries Optoelectronics Technology, Changchun, China) was used to conduct the photothermal experiments, and the thermographs were recorded using a digital IR thermal imaging camera (FLIR Systems Inc., Portland, USA). The stability of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was determined using a UV-vis spectrophotometer, FETEM, DLS, and ZP at room temperature for 12 days in DW or PBS.

In vivo fluorescent imaging experiments were performed using a customized NIR reflection mode fluorescent imaging system. A complementary metal oxide semiconductor (CMOS) camera (GS3-U3-41C6NIR-C; Point Grey Research, USA) with a camera lens (AC254-040-B; Thorlabs, Newton, NJ, USA) was employed to acquire all fluorescent images. We chose a group of filters to detect the IR783 fluorescent contrast agent: an emission filter (FF01-832/37-25; Semrock, Rochester, NY, USA), an excitation filter (FF01-769/41-25; Semrock), and a dichroic mirror (FF801-Di02-25 × 36; Semrock). A 780-nm highpower light-emitting diode (LED) (M780L3; Thorlabs) was used for irradiation for the excitation light, which was collimated using an aspheric condenser lens (ACL2520U; Thorlabs). The FlyCapture2 software version 2.13 (Point Grey Research) was used to perform the image acquisition. Finally, in order to handle the fluorescent images, we used ImageJ software (National Institutes of Health, Bethesda, MD, USA).

A photoacoustic microscopy (PAM) system was used a Q-switched diode-pumped solid-state laser (SPOT-10-100-532; Elforlight, Daventry, UK) as an excitation source. The laser operated at a repetition rate of 5 kHz with a wavelength of 532 nm and the pulsed duration of 1.8 ns. The laser light was alternately coupling into two fibers, that is, a 2 m single-mode fiber (P3-460B-FC-2; Thorlabs, USA) and one 35 m polarization-maintaining fiber (PM-S405-XP; Nufern, East Granby, CT, USA) by two fiber couplers and variable beam splitters. The output laser light of two fibers was excited the sample to produce PA waves with the energy density under 13.3 mJ/cm 2 . A home-made acoustic and optical beam combiner (OABC) was made to maximize the PA signals. A threeaxis linear motor was used to bidirectionally scan the OABC to build a volumetric image. The generated PA signals were then collected by a focused transducer (V324-SM; Olympus, USA) with a center frequency of 25 MHz. The signals were magnified by two preamplifiers (ZFL-500LN; Mini-Circuits, Brooklyn, NY, USA), and finally were acquired by a high-speed digitizer (NI PXI-5124; National Instruments, Austin, TX, USA). Data were processed to form PA images using MATLAB software. Then, the processed data were used to build a 3D image using Amira software (version 5.2.1; Thermo Fisher Scientific).

div.head: Measurement of the photothermal performance of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs
div.p: In order to measure the photothermal performance of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs, aqueous solutions of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (1 mL) at different concentrations (100, 125, 150, and 175 μg/ mL) were added in a single well of a 12-well plate and exposed to an 808 nm laser source at a density of 0.3, 0.6, 0.9, and 1.2 W/cm 2 for 300 s. Temperature changes were monitored using an IR thermal camera. The photothermal stability of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was further investigated by measuring the temperature variations in five cycles of laser irradiation followed by cooling five times at room temperature. Then, the UV-vis spectra of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs were observed and were also determined using FETEM, DLS, and ZP after laser irradiation. The photothermal conversion efficiency (η) was calculated according to earlier reports [46,47].

div.head: In vitro drug release and NIR laser-triggered release of PTX
div.p: 1 mg of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was dispersed in 2 mL of PBS, and the solution was put in a centrifuge tube with PBS at various pH conditions (5.0, 6.5, and 7.4) in a 37 °C water bath. At the designated time points, the solutions were collected for centrifugation at 15,000 rpm for 10 min, and the amount of PTX released in the supernatant was calculated using a UV-vis spectrophotometer at 235 nm. In addition, the in vitro drug release behaviors were examined under various pH conditions under laser irradiation. The samples were exposed to the 808 nm laser with a power intensity of 1.2 W/cm 2 for 300 s. The supernatants were collected to measure the PTX concentration using UV-vis spectrophotometer at 235 nm.

div.head: Cell culture and in vitro cytotoxicity
div.p: A human cervix adenocarcinoma cell line (HeLa cells) and a human breast cancer cell line (MDA-MB-231 cells) were purchased from ATCC. Cells were cultured in Dulbecco's modified Eagle's medium (DMEM; Hyclone), which includes 10% fetal bovine serum (FBS) and antibiotics (1% penicillin/streptomycin) in the atmosphere at 37 °C under 5% CO 2 . The in vitro cytotoxicity of the GNSs, TCS-GNSs, free PTX, PTX-TCS-GNSs, and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was assessed using the 3-(4,5-dimethylthiazol-2-yl)-2,5-diphenyltetrazolium bromide (MTT) assay. The HeLa cells and MDA-MB-231 cells (10,000 cells/well) were cultured on a 96-well plate and incubated for 24 h. Afterwards, the cells were cultured with GNSs, TCS-GNSs, free PTX, PTX-TCS-GNSs, and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs at different concentrations of 25, 50, 75, 100, 125, 150, 175, 200, 225, and 250 μg/mL for 24 h. After incubation, the MTT solution was placed into each well and incubated for another 4 h to quantify the cell viability. Finally, cell viability was quantified on a microplate reader (Tecan Infinite F50) at 570 nm.

div.head: In vitro hemolysis studies
div.p: For the hemocompatibility assay, heparin-stabilized blood samples were taken from nude mice and red blood cells (RBCs) were prepared by following earlier works [48]. RBCs were collected and diluted with 10× PBS. The RBCs suspension (300 μL) was treated with TCS-GNSs in 1.2 mL of PBS at various concentrations of 50, 100, 150, 175, 200, 225, and 250 μg/mL and also used as positive (DW) and negative (PBS) control, respectively. All the solutions were vortexed and incubated at 37 °C for 3 h and then centrifuged at 5000 rpm for 5 min. The absorbance of each sample was quantified on a microplate reader (Tecan Infinite F50) at 541 nm. The hemolysis of RBCs of all the samples was calculated using the following equation:

div.head: In vitro cellular uptake studies
div.p: MDA-MB-231 cells (100,000 cells/well) were cultured on 12 well plates and incubated overnight. The cells were then incubated with the culture medium containing the TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL), PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL), and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL). After various time points, the cells were washed with PBS and counted using a hemocytometer. Then, the cell pellets were completely digested with 400 μL of aqua regia, and the amount of Au was analyzed using ICP-MS.

Cells were cultured and incubated with anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL) for 8 h. Then, the cells were harvested and fixed in 3% glutaraldehyde in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.2) for 24 h at 4 °C. The samples were again fixed with 2% osmium tetroxide in 0.1 M phosphate buffer (pH 7.2) for 2 h, dehydrated in an ethanol solution and polymerized at 70 °C for 15 h. Semi-thin section was collected on copper grids and then imaged using TEM [49].

div.head: In vitro chemophotothermal therapy
div.p: For the in vitro chemophotothermal therapy, the MDA-MB-231 cells (10,000 cells/well) were cultured on a 96-well plate and incubated overnight. The cells were then treated a culture medium containing anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs at different concentrations of 25, 50, 75, 100, 125, 150, and 175 μg/mL for 5 h, and then the cells were or were not irradiated at 1.2 W/cm 2 with an 808 nm laser for 300 s. Subsequently, the cells were further cultured for 2 h and the cell viability was assessed by the MTT assay. Furthermore, the cells were incubated a culture medium containing anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL) for 5 h, and the cells were or were not irradiated at a density of 0.3, 0.6, 0.9, and 1.2 W/cm 2 with an 808 nm laser for 300 s. Afterwards, the cells were cultured for another 2 h and the cell viability was quantified by the MTT assay.

MDA-MB-231 cells (5,00,000 cells/well) were plated on a 6-well plate and incubated at 37 °C for 24 h. Then, the cells were separated into six groups, control cells only, control + laser (1.2 W/cm 2 ), free PTX (175 μg/mL) only, PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL) only, anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL) only, and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL) + laser (1.2 W/cm 2 ). After incubation for 2 h, calcein-AM and propidium iodide (PI) for live (green) and dead (red) cells were used to stain all the cells for 30 min and all the cells were imaged using a fluorescence microscope (DMI300B; Leica, Wetzlar, Germany). In addition, all the cells were stained with Hoechst 33342 and LysoTracker red for 30 min and all the cells were imaged using a two-photon fluorescence microscope (TPFM) [50]. For the apoptosis assay, the cells were cultured on a 12-well plate and incubated overnight. After incubation, the cells were separated into six groups. The cells in each group were collected, followed by washing with PBS three times, and stained followed the PI/Annexin-V assay (BD Biosciences, San Jose, CA, USA) following the manufacturer's protocols. Then, all the cells were determined using a flow cytometer (BD FACSVerse, USA).

div.head: Animal model
div.p: All animal experiments were performed in accordance with the institutional guidelines and policies of animal care services approved by the Pukyong National University. Female BALB/c nude mice (~20 g), aged between six to seven weeks, and were provided by Orient Bio Inc. (Seongnam, Republic of Korea). MDA-MB-231 cells (1 × 10 6 cells) suspended in 100 μL of PBS were injected subcutaneously into the flanks of all the mice. The animals were usable in the experiment until the tumors reached volume of ~100 mm 3 , measured using digital calipers.

div.head: Photoacoustic imaging
div.p: An in vitro and in vivo photoacoustic microscopy (PAM) system was used according to earlier reports [51,52]. For in vitro PAI, MDA-MB-231 cells were incubated with different concentrations of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (125, 150, and 175 μg/mL) at 37 °C for 6 h. After trypsin digestion, the cells were collected by centrifugation at 1500 rpm for 3 min. The cell pellets were then loaded into a polytetrafluoroethylene (PTFE) tube (Zeus) and used for PAI. For in vivo PAI, MDA-MB-231 tumor-bearing nude mice were injected with anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL) intravenously through a single tail vein. The PAI of the whole tumor region was scanned by the PAM system at 0 h and 6 h after the injection.

div.head: In vivo fluorescence imaging and accumulation analysis
div.p: An near-infrared dye (IR783) was loaded into anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs according to earlier work [53]. MDA-MB-231 tumor-bearing nude mice were given IR783/anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (100 μg of IR783/kg) via a tail vein injection, and in vivo time-dependent distribution at different time points (1, 2, 3, 6, 8, 12, and 24 h) was performed using a customized NIR reflection mode fluorescent imaging system. Then, the mice were euthanized and the organs, including the heart, liver, lung, kidney, and spleen, and tumors were taken and then washed with cold PBS for ex vivo fluorescence (FL) imaging by a customized NIR reflection mode fluorescent imaging system. After ex vivo fluorescence imaging, the organs and blood were taken, digested with aqua regia, and measured for Au content by an ICP-MS.

div.head: In vivo chemophotothermal therapy
div.p: The MDA-MB-231 tumor-bearing mice were separated into six groups (n = 5 per group) and then systemically given saline only (Group I, 0.9%), saline + laser (Group II, 0.9%, 1.2 W/cm 2 ), free PTX only (Group III, 175 μg/mL), PTX-TCS-GNSs only (Group IV, 175 μg/ mL), anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs only (Group V, 175 μg/mL), and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs + laser (Group VI, 175 μg/mL, 1.2 W/cm 2 ) through a single tail vein injection. After 5 h of injection, the tumors in the samples of Group II and VI were exposed to an 808 nm laser at a density of 1.2 W/cm 2 for 300 s. During irradiation, an IR thermal camera was used to record the temperature changes of the tumor regions. Then, the body weight and tumor volume of the mice were recorded every two days.

All mice were killed after treatment. Fresh organs, including the heart, liver, lung, kidney, and spleen, and tumor tissues of various groups were excised, fixed in 10% neutral buffered formalin, dehydrated, embedded with paraffin, and sectioned (6 μm) for hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) staining. Histopathological images were examined under a digital microscope. At 24 h posttreatment, tumor tissues were excised for H&E staining. In addition, the tumor tissue sections were used to detect cell apoptosis by terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase triphosphate (dUTP) nick end labeling (TUNEL, In Situ Cell Death Detection Kit, Roche Diagnostics, Mannheim, Germany) assays. After treatment, the organs of various groups were collected, digested with aqua regia, and measured for Au content by an ICP-MS.

div.head: Statistical analysis
div.p: All the data were expressed as the mean ± standard deviation (SD). Statistical analyses were carried out using one-way analysis of variance. Origin 8.0 software was used to analyze the data.

div.head: Preparation and characterization of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs
div.p: The overall synthesis of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs as a novel multifunctional theranostic agent for fluorescence/PA dual-modal imagingguided chemophotothermal synergistic therapy is illustrated in Scheme 1, Figs.S1, and S2. GNSs were synthesized using the modified Oldenburg method [34], and the amino groups present in the CS were conjugated with carboxyl groups located on dithiol ligands such as LA, through carbodiimide chemistry (TCS). The decoration of GNSs with TCS was successfully synthesized through covalent gold-thiol linkages (TCS-GNSs). PTX was directly conjugated to the free amino groups present in the TCS via a condensation reaction (PTX-TCS-GNSs). Finally, the anti-EGFR antibody was covalently conjugated to the free amino groups present in the TCS (PTX-TCS-GNSs) through carbodiimide chemistry in a buffer solution (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs). According to the BCA protein assay, the antibody conjugation efficiency was determined to be 74.58%, suggesting that the antibody was successfully conjugated [44]. The free PTX solution was recorded by UV-vis spectrophotometer and it showed the maximum peak at 228 nm (Fig. S3). The free PTX solution did not show any peak in the 300-900 nm. The UV-vis-NIR spectra revealed that the surface plasmon resonance (SPR) peaks for GNSs, TCS-GNSs, PTX-TCS-GNSs, and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs showed strong absorbance in the NIR region (700-1200 nm), and they showed an SPR absorption peak at 799 nm (Fig. 1a). Therefore, the surface of the GNSs was decorated by TCS, a biocompatible polymer. The TCS modification did not affect the SPR absorption peak of GNSs, which could greatly improve the colloidal stability. You et al. demonstrated that the SPR peaks at 800 nm for hollow gold nanospheres (HAuNSs) and polyethylene-glycol-(PEG) coated HAuNSs were tuned to the NIR region [54].

FETEM images show the structure of the silica core, GNSs, TCS-GNSs, PTX-TCS-GNSs, and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (Figs. S4-S8 and Fig. 1b). The silica core has an average diameter of ~120 nm and an average GNS thickness of ~9 nm. Similar results have reported by Norregaard et al. [55] demonstrating that the gold nanoshells contain a silica core of 120 nm in diameter surrounded by a 15 nm thick gold shell. After surface modification of GNSs, the TCS with a thickness of ~4 nm was uniformly covered around the surface of the GNSs (TCS-GNSs). After loading with PTX, PTX-TCS-GNSs showed a uniform morphology with a thickness of ~6 nm. After anti-EGFR conjugation with PTX-TCS-GNSs, anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs showed a faint layer surrounding the darker GNSs with a thickness of ~7 nm. Our FETEM images were similar to the previous report using doxorubicin-loaded PEG-hollow gold nanospheres (DOX@PEG-HAuNS), which clearly showed a DOX layer with a thickness of about 4-6 nm covering the surface of DOX@PEG-HAuNS [54]. The FETEM and corresponding EDX spectrum of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was used to further confirm the formation of the silicon (Si) and gold (Au) nanoshells. It showed that the strong Au, Si, C, and O signal appeared in the EDX spectrum of the product (Fig. S9a,b). Furthermore, the EDX map for Au, Si, C, and O was observed to demonstrate the presence of four elements in anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (Fig. S10). The EDX mapping images clearly demonstrate that the formation of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs wherein Au (green color) was distributed in the outer layers and the inner Si (orange color) was distributed annularly along with the outer GNSs. In addition, the morphologies of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs were further confirmed by HAADF-STEM, which showed a uniform morphology (Fig. S11). A HAADF-STEM-EDX mapping shows the presence of Au, Si, C, and O and confirmed the presence of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (Fig. S12). Similar results were observed by You et al. [56]. The size distributions of GNSs, TCS-GNSs, PTX-TCS-GNSs, and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs were determined by DLS to be approximately 128.37 ± 3.41 nm, 133.11 ± 2.52 nm, 134.82 ± 1.48 nm, and 135.98 ± 2.36 nm, respectively (Fig. 1c). In addition, GNSs were negatively charged with a zeta potential (ZP) of -41.36 ± 2.06 mV in a PBS (pH 7.4) solution, and TCS, TCS-GNSs, PTX-TCS-GNSs, and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs were positively charged with an effective ZP of +36.21 ± 1.81 mV, +45.24 ± 2.26 mV, +48.51 ± 4.42 mV, and + 49.87 ± 3.49 mV, respectively (Fig. 1d).

Fig. 1e shows the FTIR spectra of GNSs, CS, TCS, TCS-GNSs, PTX, PTX-TCS-GNSs, and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs. GNSs showed a peak at 1151 cm -1 and 788 cm -1 , corresponding to the Si-O-Si bond, and a peak at 946 cm -1 corresponding to the Si-OH bond. CS showed some characteristic peaks at 1645 cm -1 , 1570 cm -1 , 1179 cm -1 , and 1030 cm -1 , which can be assigned to the C]O, NeH, CeOeC, and CeO bonds, respectively. After surface modification of GNSs with TCS, the characteristic peak of the TCS was present at 1570 cm -1 , corresponding to the NeH bond, and the major peaks of GNSs appeared at 1151 cm -1 , corresponding to the SieOeSi asymmetric vibration. These peaks confirm the successful formation of TCS-GNSs. The PTX revealed stretching regions for CeC at 1664 cm -1 , for CeN at 1263 cm -1 , and for CeO at 1083 cm -1 . After loading with PTX, the spectrum of the PTX on the TCS-GNSs exhibited peaks of PTX that shifted from 1664 cm -1 , 1263 cm -1 , and 1083 cm -1 to 1682 cm -1 , 1272 cm -1 , and 1086 cm -1 , respectively, and the characteristic peaks of TCS-GNSs appeared, indicating that PTX was successfully loaded into TCS-GNSs (PTX-TCS-GNSs). After anti-EGFR conjugation with PTX-TCS-GNSs, the characteristic peaks of PTX-TCS-GNSs appeared and the major peak associated with the anti-EGFR antibody at 1710 cm -1 was present on anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs, suggesting that the anti-EGFR conjugated at the surface of PTX-TCS-GNSs through the amide linkages. Similar results were observed by Zhang et al. [57] and Zhou et al. [26]. The chemical structures of CS, LA, and TCS were further confirmed by the 1H NMR spectra (Fig. S13). The spectrum for CS exhibited peaks for the methyl, ethyl, and sugar protons of the structure between 1.8 and 3.8 ppm. The proton peaks in the LA were observed at 1.2-1.6, 1.8, 2.2–2.8, 3.1, and 3.6 ppm. Compared with CS and LA, new proton peaks in TCS appeared at 0.9–2.4, 2.7–3.2, and 3.4–3.8 ppm, suggesting that TCS was successfully synthesized. Similar results have reported by Elsaid et al. [58] and [26]. According to the TNBS method, the degree of amino substitution of TCS (TCS-GNSs), DTPA-TCS (PTX-TCS-GNSs), and anti-EGFR-TCS (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) were determined to be 23.7%, 18.4%, and 15.2% indicating that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was successfully conjugated [59].

Thermal stability of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was investigated using a TG/DTA and the obtained results presented in Fig. S14. The anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was heated from room temperature to 800 °C with an increment of 10 °C/min in air atmosphere. The TG curves show that first weight loss (10%) was observed at 70 °C, suggesting that the excess water molecules started to evaporate from the sample. The second mass loss (30%) was observed from 100 °C-250 °C, the third mass loss (56%) was observed from 250 °C-350 °C, and the fourth mass loss (79%) was observed from 350 °C-580 °C, which could be attributed to the removal of organic matter. Above 580 °C to 800 °C, the TG curve is straight and linear, suggesting no weight loss in the sample. In the DTA curve, two exothermic peaks at 327 °C and 547 °C were observed and two endothermic peaks at 55 °C and 482 °C, which may be related to evaporate the excess water along with decompositions of inorganic matter. Our TG/DTA result is similar to those in previous results and major peaks were observed in a different place due to the use of various reagents in their synthesis [60,61].

The stability of nanomaterials in a biosystem is essential, especially in biomedical applications. Anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs were dispersed in DW and PBS (pH 7.4) for 12 days and the optical property of the aqueous dispersion of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was characterized using UV-vis spectrophotometer. As shown in Fig. S15a,b, no obvious difference was observed in DW and PBS for 5 min and 12 days, indicating that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs were more stable. The FETEM image of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs shows a uniform morphology in PBS buffer after 12 days (Fig. S16). In addition, the size of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs in the PBS buffer before and after 12 days was characterized by DLS approximately to be 135.98 ± 2.36 nm and 134.21 ± 1.83 nm, respectively. The ZP of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs in the PBS buffer before and after 12 days was determined to be +49.87 ± 3.49 mV and +49.03 ± 4.52 mV, respectively. As previously reported, the stability of PEG-coated gold nanorods were investigated under biological conditions such as PBS, saline solutions, and various pH, which was highly stable under various biological conditions [62].

div.head: Measurement of the photothermal performance of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs
div.p: The optical property of the aqueous dispersion of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs with different concentrations (100, 125, 150, and 175 μg/ mL) was characterized using a UV-vis spectrophotometer. Anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs showed strong NIR absorption, a high optical transparency window, whereas blood, water, and biological tissue absorb minimally (Fig. 1f). The photothermal performance of aqueous solutions of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs at different concentrations (100, 125, 150, and 175 μg/mL) were added in a single well of a 12-well plate and exposed to the 808 nm laser source at a density of 0.3 W/cm 2 (Fig. S17a), 0.6 W/cm 2 (Fig. S17b), 0.9 W/cm 2 (Fig. S17c), and 1.2 W/cm 2 (Fig. 2a) for 300 s. In particular, the temperature of the aqueous anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs solution (175 μg/mL) increased to 52.7 °C after continuous irradiation at 1.2 W/cm 2 for 300 s, which is sufficient for in vivo cancer therapy because tumor cells can be selectively killed at a temperature above that of hyperthermia (42-47 °C) [63]. By contrast, insufficient heating with a temperature increase of only 29.1 °C was recorded for DW, suggesting that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs are a promising material for PTT. In addition, the temperature of the aqueous anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs solution (175 μg/mL) was exposed to the 808 nm laser source at four different powers (0.3, 0.6, 0.9, and 1.2 W/ cm 2 ) for 300 s, resulting in the temperature values of 37.6 °C, 41.2 °C, 46.4 °C, and 52.7 °C, respectively (Fig. 2b). The photothermal performance of aqueous anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs solutions was further investigated using an IR thermal camera. The temperature changes of the aqueous anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs solution (175 μg/mL) under 808 nm laser exposure of 0.3 W/cm 2 , 0.6 W/cm 2 , 0.9 W/cm 2 , and 1.2 W/cm 2 for 300 s were captured using an IR thermal camera (Fig. S18).

The photothermal conversion efficiency plays a significant role in the PTT of nanomaterials [64]. To evaluate the photothermal conversion efficiency (η) of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs aqueous solution, the solution (175 μg/mL) was exposed to the 808 nm laser source at 1.2 W/cm 2 for 300 s. The laser was turned on for about 300 s in each cycle, and then it was turned off for about 900 s in each cycle (Fig. 2c). Afterward, the aqueous solution was allowed to cool to room temperature, which can be shown in a typical photothermal profile (Fig. S19). The value of t s was 292.3 s. The photothermal conversion efficiency (η) was calculated to be 32.63% from the equation, indicating that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs have excellent photothermal conversion ability, which significantly exceeded those of classic photothermal agents including, gold nanorods (21%) and Cu 2-x S nanocrystals (16.3%) [65,66]. Similar results have also been reported by Cole et al. [67] indicating that the photothermal conversion efficiency of SiO 2 /Au nanoshells was calculated to be 30%.

The photothermal stability of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL) aqueous solution was further confirmed by the 808 nm laser source at 1.2 W/cm 2 for 300 s. The laser was turned on for about 300 s in each cycle, and then it was turned off for about 900 s in each cycle. As shown in Fig. 2d, no obvious changes in the temperature were recorded for anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL) after five cycles of laser on/laser off. Therefore, it was concluded that the synthesized anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs possess excellent photothermal stability. The optical property of the aqueous anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs solution was further characterized using a UV-vis spectrophotometer before and after continuous irradiation of five cycles and the UV-vis-NIR spectra showed no observable changes in the absorbance after continuous irradiation (Fig. S20). The FETEM image also indicates that the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs showed a uniform size after continuous irradiation for five cycles (Fig. S21). The particle size of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs after continuous irradiation for five cycles was found by DLS to be approximately 134.96 ± 3.72 nm. The ZP of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs after continuous irradiation for five cycles was +48.93 ± 2.61 mV, indicating that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs have excellent photothermal stability after continuous laser irradiation. As demonstrated by previous works, the temperature changes of nanomaterials were almost constant after continuous irradiation for five cycles of laser on/laser off, suggesting good photothermal stability under laser irradiation [68,69].

div.head: PTX loading and NIR laser-triggered drug release
div.p: PTX was conjugated to the PTX-TCS-GNSs through a condensation reaction, forming anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs. The drug entrapment efficiency and drug loading efficiency of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs were 78.47 ± 1.32% and 13.61 ± 0.84%, respectively. The release profiles of PTX from anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs in PBS at pH 5.0, 6.5, and 7.4, with or without 808 nm laser irradiation, were studied, and PTX was released more and faster at pH 5.0 than at pH 7.4, indicating that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs release PTX faster under weakly acidic conditions (Fig. 2e). pH-dependent drug release is important in clinical applications because normal tissues are neutral at pH 7.4 and the microenvironments of extracellular tissues of tumors and intracellular organelles such as lysosomes and endosomes are acidic at pH 5.0 [70,71]. At pH 5.0, the cumulative release of PTX was significantly increased from 64.83% to 80.76% within 48 h under 808 nm laser exposure. At pH 7.4, the PTX release from anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was extremely slow at 48 h from 15.87% to 23.89% under laser irradiation. These results indicate that acidic conditions and laser irradiation facilitate PTX release from the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs, showing that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs are excellent candidates for drug delivery applications. Similar results have also been reported by Ren et al. [71] suggesting that both acidic conditions and heating induced by NIR laser could facilitate PTX release from the nano-drugs, which is suitable for drug's controllable release regulated by the pH value and NIR light.

The PTX release from anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs triggered by NIR laser was further investigated at pH 5.0. The PTX release was 14.34% from anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs at 6 h at pH 5.0 without laser irradiation, whereas at the same treatment conditions, the release of PTX was significantly increased to 25.14% when anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs were exposed to an 808 nm laser source at 1.2 W/cm 2 for 300 s and the release of PTX was very slow once the NIR laser was switched off for the next hour (Fig. 2f). After an additional four cycles of laser on for 300 s at 12 h, 18 h, 30 h, and 42 h, the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs exhibited 91.09% drug release up to 48 h, much higher than that the PTX was released of 53.83% at 48 h without irradiation, suggesting that apart from the acidic conditions, NIR laser-induced heat can function as an inducement to laser on-off control the release of PTX from anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs [27]. As previously reported, PTX was released more and fast at pH 5.0 and about 81.2% of PTX was released at 48 h after four cycles of 5 min laser irradiation because of the heat generated by graphene oxide when absorbing NIR light, which weakens the noncovalent absorption interactions between PTX and graphene oxide [27].

div.head: In vitro cytotoxicity and hemolysis studies
div.p: The in vitro cytotoxicity of the GNSs, TCS-GNSs, free PTX, PTX-TCS-GNSs, and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was assessed in the HeLa cells and MDA-MB-231 cells using the MTT assay. The HeLa cells and MDA-MB-231 cells were cultured with GNSs, TCS-GNSs, free PTX, PTX-TCS-GNSs and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs at different concentrations 25, 50, 75, 100, 125, 150, 175, 200, 225, and 250 μg/mL for 24 h. The viabilities of the HeLa cells and MDA-MB-231 cells were found to be above 71% at a high concentration of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs up to 250 μg/mL for 24 h, exhibiting a relatively low toxicity to cancer cells (Fig. S22 and Fig. 3a). These results indicate that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs have very low toxicity to cancer cells and tissues. As shown in Fig. S22 and Fig. 3a, no obvious differences were observed above 95% at a high concentration of TCS-GNSs up to 250 μg/mL for 24 h, suggesting that the synthesized TCS-GNSs appear to be largely biocompatible. Lv et al. reported the relative cell viability of A549, B16F1, HeLa, and MCF-7 treated with the 3,3′-dithiodipropionic acid-functionalized poly(ethylene glycol)-b-poly(L-lysine) (mPEG-b-P(LL-DTPA)), which were found to be above 85% at a high concentration of mPEG-b-P(LL-DTPA) up to 1000 μg/mL for 48 h, indicating the remarkable safety and biocompatibility of mPEG-b-P(LL-DTPA) [43]. For the in vivo cancer therapy of TCS-GNSs, the hemocompatibility assay is a crucial toxicological factor that must be investigated. As shown in Fig. 3b, TCS-GNSs showed hemolytic activities of 5.21 ± 0.26% at a high concentration of 250 μg/mL, showing the good blood compatibility of the nanomaterials. Similar results have been suggested by Feng et al. [48], polyelectrolyte multilayer functionalized mesoporous silica nanoparticles (PEM-MSNs) showed a hemolysis percentage of lower than 1% at a high concentration of PEM-MSNs up to 800 μg/mL, suggesting that PEM-MSN-treated RBCs exhibited no noticeable hemolytic activities.

div.head: In vitro cellular uptake studies
div.p: The cellular uptake behaviors of TCS-GNSs, PTX-TCS-GNSs, and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs in MDA-MB-231 cells were quantified by an ICP-MS. As illustrated in Fig. 3c, the intercellular uptake of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs gradually increased as the incubation time increased from 1 h to 5 h and the amount of Au was measured to be 73.35 ± 3.66 pg per cell at 5 h compared to 21.78 ± 1.0 pg per cell for nonspecific TCS-GNSs and 23.46 ± 1.17 pg per cell for nonspecific PTX-TCS-GNSs, suggesting that the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs exhibited enhanced cellular uptake because of their efficient and fast receptormediated endocytosis process [72]. Similar results have been suggested by Zhang et al. [73], the intracellular uptake amount of gold nanocages (AuNCs@DBPP) per cell increased with incubation time from 1 to 8 h, which was higher than that of DOX@AuNCs at the same incubation time, suggesting that biotin receptor-mediated endocytosis could facilitate the cellular uptake of AuNCs@DBPP. Furthermore, the cellular uptake of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs were also confirmed by TEM in MDA-MB-231 cells (Fig. S23a). The anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs were localized mostly in the endocytotic vesicles and some of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs were localized in the nucleus as well as in other cytoplasmic organelles. Similar results were observed by Tiwari et al. [74]. In addition, the EDX spectrum of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs collected from intracellular vesicles exhibited the Au signals because of the receptor-mediated endocytosis process (Fig. S23b).

div.head: In vitro chemophotothermal therapy
div.p: In order to assess the chemophotothermal efficiency of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs, in vitro cytotoxicity was measured using the MTT assay. MDA-MB-231 cells were incubated with a culture medium containing anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs at different concentrations 25, 50, 75, 100, 125, 150, and 175 μg/mL for 5 h, and then the cells were or were not irradiated at 1.2 W/cm 2 with an 808 nm laser for 300 s (Fig. 3d). After further incubation for 2 h, the cell viability without 808 nm laser irradiation was 81.55% at the highest concentration of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs up to 175 μg/mL, indicating no noticeable effect on the cells. The majority of the cells were killed after being incubated with anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL) and exposed to an 808 nm laser source at 1.2 W/cm 2 for 300 s, and the cell viability decreased to 20.48%, suggesting that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs have potential as highly efficient PTT nanomaterials for cancer therapy. Furthermore, the cells were treated with a culture medium containing anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL) for 5 h and the cells were or were not irradiated at a density of 0.3, 0.6, 0.9, and 1.2 W/cm 2 with an 808 nm laser for 300 s (Fig. 3e). The cells were efficiently killed by anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs at a concentration of 175 μg/mL with 808 nm laser exposure; > 80% of the cells were killed, suggesting that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs have a significant photothermal effect and may act as an efficient photothermal agent for in vivo cancer treatment. As demonstrated by previous work, the multifunctional Au@carbon/calcium phosphate core-shell nanoparticles (Au@C/CaP NPs) with laser irradiation show relatively higher cell toxicity, suggesting that the combination of the chemo-photothermal therapy of the Au@C/CaP NPs could significantly improve the efficacy of the cancer cell death [75].

In order to further identify cell viability, all the groups of MDA-MB-231 cells were stained with calcein-AM and PI for live (green) and dead (red) cells by fluorescence microscopy (Fig. 3f, Fig. S24, and Fig. 4). In the control groups, all the cells showed green fluorescence and few dead cells were observed. By contrast, the cells were treated with anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs and then exposed to an 808 nm laser source at 1.2 W/cm 2 for 300 s. The cells exhibited strong red fluorescence, indicating that they were completely killed. As previously reported, fluorescence staining using calcein-AM and PI was investigated for visualization of live and dead cells and the HeLa cells were incubated Au@C/CaP NPs under laser irradiation, a large red area is discovered, indicating that the Au@C/CaP NPs with laser irradiation can effectively kill the cancer cells [75]. In order to further investigate the chemophotothermal efficiency of using a TPFM, all the groups of cells were stained with Hoechst 33342 and LysoTracker red and two special fluorescent tracers were used to label the nucleus and lysosomes, respectively (Fig. 5). The cells were treated with anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs under laser irradiation, Hoechst 33342 was clearly observed fragmented nuclei, and the strong red fluorescence signal was mainly distributed within lysosomes, indicating that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs were uptaken via receptor-mediated endocytosis pathway and then more PTX was released from the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs in the lysosomes. In contrast, most of the cells in the control and laser only group showed normal nuclei and free PTX alone, PTX-TCS-GNSs alone, and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs alone showed negligible cell death. These results indicated that the internalized anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs under laser irradiation was delivered to lysosomes where the acidic condition accelerated the release and then promoted the nuclei entrance of PTX, which was consistent with previous results that NIR laser-induced heat by nanomaterials could trigger the endosomal escape of drugs [76][77][78]. In addition, the cell death induced by anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was further evaluated using a PI/Annexin V staining kit and determined using a flow cytometer (Fig. S25). The anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs + laser-treated cells exhibited an 81.9% apoptosis rate, which was higher than those of free PTX (25.45%), PTX-TCS-GNSs (17.15%), and anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (13.27%), indicating a significant photothermal therapeutic effect of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs under laser irradiation (Fig. S26). Similar results were observed by Liu et al. [79], the tumor cells were treated with indocyanine green (ICG)containing mesoporous silica-coated gold nanorods (I-TMSG) and then double-labeled with PI/Annexin V, suggesting that the I-TMSG plus laser irradiation was significantly induced tumor cell necrosis/late apoptosis (72.9%) compared with control groups (12.7%).

div.head: Photoacoustic imaging
div.p: Recently, PAI has emerged as a rapidly developing noninvasive imaging technology for biomedical applications, which has the capability to analyze the accumulation of nanomaterials in tumors tissues [80]. Fig. 6a shows an experimental setup of a tunable color PAM system. For in vitro PAI, MDA-MB-231 cells were incubated at various concentrations (125, 150, and 175 μg/mL) at 37 °C for 6 h. After trypsin digestion, the cells were harvested and loaded into a PTFE tube and used for PAI (Fig. S27 and Fig. 6b). As evidenced in Fig. S28a, b, a higher PA signal was detected from the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL), indicating the ability of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs to act as a new PAI contrast agent.

For in vivo PAI, the MDA-MB-231 tumor-bearing nude mice were injected with 0.1 mL of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (175 μg/mL) intravenously through a single tail vein (Fig. 6c). First, the PAI of the whole tumor region was scanned using the PAM system with laser (wavelength: 532 nm) at 0 h and 6 h after injection (Fig. 6d,>e). The PA signal of hemoglobin levels at 532 nm was generally higher because of the blood vessel and the PA signal of the same area of the tumor at 532 nm was used as a control at 0 h. The PA signal of the same area of the tumor was higher at 6 h after injection by a 532 nm laser compared with control at 0 h, displaying the high targeting efficiency of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs and the great potential of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs for PAI (Supplementary Videos S1 and S2).

Second, the PAI of the same area of the tumor was scanned by the PAM system with laser (wavelength: 532-1000 nm) at 0 h and 6 h (Fig. 6d). The control at 0 h showed a weak PA signal, and the blood vessels in the tumor region were found because of the presence of hemoglobin as an endogenous contrast agent [81]. The anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs-treated mice showed a higher PA signal in the tumor region compared with the control at 0 h. Finally, the PAI of the tumor region was scanned by the PAM system with laser (wavelength: 625-1000 nm) at 0 h and 6 h after injection (Fig. 6d). The tumor showed a very low PA signal at 0 h because of the very low intrinsic absorption of hemoglobin. However, PAI showed a clear tumor microstructure with high contrast and a high spatial resolution at 6 h of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs because of the high NIR absorption in the nanomaterials (Fig. S29), suggesting that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs show a powerful capability to visualize tumors and are a new PAI contrast agent for subsequent chemophotothermal therapy [82]. Similar results have reported by Phan et al. [56] indicating that the hyaluronan (HA)-coated FeOOH@polypyrrole (FeOOH@PPy) nanorods (HA-FeOOH@PPy NRs) can serve as PA contrast agents for cancer therapy using PAM system.

div.head: In vivo fluorescence (FL) imaging and accumulation analysis
div.p: The biodistribution and tumor targeting of nanomaterials labeled with the NIR dye (IR783) in tumor-bearing nude mice were investigated using a whole animal NIR reflection mode fluorescent imaging system. The fluorescence (FL) images of MDA-MB-231 tumor-bearing nude mice were obtained at different time points (1, 2, 3, 6, 8, 12, and 24 h) after the intravenous injection of IR783/anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (Fig. 7a). The fluorescence signals were found in the whole body within 6 h because of the blood flow of IR783 [53]. The fluorescence signals in the tumor region were obviously enhanced within 6 h, and the fluorescence signals were gradually decreased after 6 h, indicating that 6 h after injection was the optimum time period for the in vivo chemophotothermal therapy (Fig. 7b). Our in vivo FL imaging is similar to previous results and IR783/hyaluronic acid-hollow mesoporous copper sulfide nanoparticles (HMCuS-HA NPs) showed highest FL signals in tumor area at about 8 h, suggesting that HMCuS-HA NPs significantly enhanced accumulation in the tumor through enhanced permeability and retention (EPR) effect [53].

In addition, the distribution of IR783/anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was further confirmed by ex vivo imaging at 24 h after injection, and the organs, including the heart, liver, lung, kidney, and spleen, as well as the tumor were excised and analyzed (Fig. 7c). As shown in Fig. 7d, the fluorescence signals of IR783/anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs at the tumor region were significantly higher compared with other organs because of the receptor-mediated endocytosis pathway, which showed an excellent tumor targeting efficacy [53,83]. In order to further quantitatively measure the in vivo biodistribution of IR783/anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs, the organs and blood of mice were harvested and measured for Au content by an ICP-MS. Interestingly, the amount of Au element in the tumor at 6 h was over 6.28% ID/g (injection dosage per gram of tissue), which was significantly higher than in other organs and in the blood, suggesting a higher tumor targeting efficiency of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs (Fig. 7e). After 24 h, the residual anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs in most of the organs and blood decreased appreciably, suggesting the effective clearance of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs. Similar results were observed by Feng et al. [53].

div.head: In vivo chemophotothermal therapy
div.p: We have investigated the combination therapy of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs. After the tumor size reached ~100 mm 3 , the MDA-MB-231 tumor-bearing mice were separated into six groups through a single tail vein injection (n = 5 per group). After 5 h of injection, the tumors in the samples of Group II and VI were exposed to an 808 nm laser at a density of 1.2 W/cm 2 for 300 s. The local tumor temperature in the Group II (saline) and Group VI (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) samples with laser irradiation was imaged using an IR thermal camera (Fig. 8a). As shown in Fig. 8b, the local temperature change of the tumor in the Group VI (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) samples with laser irradiation increased and reached a very high temperature of 61.9 °C within 300 s, which was highly sufficient to effectively ablate tumors in vivo. As previously reported, the temperature of tumors on mice injected with bacterial magnetic nanoparticles (BMPs) rapidly reached to 57 °C in 3 min, which was sufficient for fast induction of cancer cells necrosis [84]. By contrast, the local tumor temperature in the Group II (saline) with laser irradiation reached 34.6 °C, which was insufficient to thermally ablate tumor cells [84,85]. After the treatment, no animals died in the groups and no observable differences were observed in the body weights of mice (Fig. 8c), suggesting that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs have excellent biocompatibility and their photothermal effect did not cause any noticeable toxicity in vivo [84]. Then, the tumor volume of the mice was measured every two days, and it was found that the tumors grew fast in all control groups of mice during the course of treatment (Fig. 8d). As shown in Fig. S30, a 97.43% tumor inhibition rate was observed in Group VI (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) with laser irradiation, which was compared with all other groups, indicating a suitable condition for highly ablating tumors in vivo.

Figs. S31a and S32 shows the digital photographs of mice in all the groups taken during the process of in vivo chemophotothermal therapy. Notably, the tumors in Group VI (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) with laser irradiation were highly ablated and no recurrence was detected, even after 16 more days of feeding. In the previous report, gold assemblies (GAs) could act as an efficient photothermal agent for cancer therapy to fully eliminate tumor in vivo [86]. Furthermore, the survival rates of mice were monitored during the course of treatment (Fig. 8e). The survival rate over 34 days was 100% in Group VI (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) with laser irradiation compared with all other groups, suggesting that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs + laser has a good chemophotothermal efficiency and excellent biocompatibility. Previous reports also showed that the BMPs have excellent biocompatibility [84]. After the treatment, the tumors were excised (Fig. S31b), and it was found that the tumor weights in Group VI (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) with laser irradiation were smaller than in all other groups (Fig. S33).

In order to further confirm the chemophotothermal effect of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs, histological analysis of tumor cell death was performed by tumor sections using H&E staining and TUNEL staining at 24 h posttreatment. As shown in Fig. S34, significant tumor necrosis, and more apoptotic cells were recorded in Group VI (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) with laser irradiation, when compared with all other groups in the tumor showed no or very few apoptotic cells, suggesting that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs injected tumor cells were severely destroyed after laser irradiation [86]. Previous reports also proved that GA7 injected tumor cells were severely damaged after laser irradiation [86]. The TUNEL assay was also investigated and a strong green signal was observed in the tumor tissue of Group VI (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) with laser irradiation, whereas in all other groups, a very weak green signal was observed, indicating that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs could efficiently inhibit tumor growth after laser irradiation (Fig. S35). The apoptotic tumor cells in Group VI (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) with laser irradiation were 42.34% in comparison with all other groups (Fig. S36). After treatment, no tumor tissues were observed in Group VI (anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs) with laser irradiation. Histological analysis of the organs of healthy mice was performed after 16 days after treatment, and no observable histopathological abnormalities or inflammation was observed (Fig. S37), indicating that anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs with laser irradiation are highly effective photothermal agents for tumor therapy [1]. Furthermore, the biodistribution of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs with laser irradiation was analyzed after 24 h and 16 days posttreatment by an ICP-MS. As evidenced in Fig. S38, the amount of Au element in the tumor within 24 h after injection was calculated to be 5.03% ID/g, which is much larger than that for all other organs, and no tumor tissues were observed in anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs with laser irradiation 16 days after treatment, showing a safe and a higher targeting efficiency of the anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs [87].

div.head: Conclusions
div.p: In this study, a novel multifunctional theranostic agent, anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs was developed for the first time and used for NIR laser-triggered drug release in combined chemophotothermal therapy under the guidance of PAI. Anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs showed excellent biocompatibility, biosafety, stability, photostability, broad NIR absorbance, and high targeting efficiency. In addition, anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs exhibited high drug loading capabilities, pH and NIR laser dualresponsive chemotherapy, and high photothermal conversion efficiency, demonstrating that chemophotothermal synergistic therapy with PAI is highly efficient for the treatment of cancer. The in vitro cancer cells ablation efficiency was significantly reduced after laser irradiation. Notably, the in vivo chemophotothermal treatment of anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs with laser irradiation was highly ablated and no recurrence was detected. Anti-EGFR-PTX-TCS-GNSs exhibited high biosafety with excellent biocompatibility as confirmed by histopathological analyses. In future, understanding the molecular mechanisms of cancer therapy is very important and more extensive animal experimentation and well-controlled clinical trials are needed for further studies. We believe that this work will provide a new concept and strategy for the development of a novel multifunctional nanotheranostic agent for future clinical applications in the diagnosis and therapy of cancer.
Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.jconrel.2019.08.007.

div.head: Author contributions
div.p: P.M., V.T.N, and S.W.J contributed equally to this work. P.M., J.O., and C.S.K. conceived the idea and supervised this work. V.T.N, and J.K. conducted the PAI and analyzed the 3D PAI. G.H., S.M., S.W.J., and H.K. synthesized the nanomaterials and performed the characterization of nanomaterials. S.W.J. and C.S.K. conducted the TPFM. V.H.M.D. designed the graphical abstract and scheme image. The manuscript was written through contributions of all authors. All authors have given approval to the final version of the manuscript.
